questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in her 16th week of gestation presents with abdominal discomfort and bloating. Ultrasound reveals bilateral cysts in the ovaries measuring 10 cm in diameter. Serum beta-hCG levels are significantly elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of bilateral ovarian cysts measuring 10 cm in diameter and significantly elevated serum beta-hCG levels is highly suggestive of theca lutein cysts. Elevated hCG is the main cause of the formation of theca lutein cysts

 

Theca lutein cysts are often noted in cases of:

  • Multiple gestations

  • Hydatidiform moles

  • Choriocarcinoma

  • Induction of ovulation with gonadotropin (hCG) and clomiphene

 

Non-neoplastic cysts are mostly treated conservatively. The types are:

  • Follicular cysts

  • Corpus luteal cysts

  • Hemorrhagic cyst

  • Theca lutein cysts

 

Follicular cyst (Option A): Follicular cysts form when an incompletely developed follicle fails to absorb fluid or during anovulation. They can be single or multiple, bilateral, and vary in size from small to large, but generally do not exceed 5.0 cm in diameter

 

Corpus luteal cyst (Option B): Corpus luteum cysts never grow larger than 7 cm in size and are unilocular with clear fluid.

 

Hemorrhagic cyst (Option D): Hemorrhagic cysts are follicular hematomas and present as cysts. Old cysts contain tan-coloured material, which may be mistaken for endometriosis. A cyst may rupture into the peritoneal cavity, causing an acute abdomen that is mistaken for an ectopic pregnancy

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman has presented with abdominal distension and discomfort for the past few months. On examination, there is bilateral pelvic tenderness with a palpable pelvic mass. Ultrasound confirms a large cystic lesion 8-10 cm in the right ovary with irregular solid areas. Serum CA-125 levels are elevated.

Which of the following epithelial ovarian tumors is most likely to present with the described clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Serous cystadenocarcinoma is the most common epithelial ovarian carcinoma, typically presenting with bilateral ovarian involvement, elevated CA-125 levels, and a mix of cystic and solid components on imaging.

 

Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma often presents with unilateral ovarian involvement and is less likely to be associated with elevated CA-125 levels. (Option A)

 

Types of Epithelial Ovarian Tumor:

Type of Epithelial Ovarian Tumor

Characteristics

Clinical Presentation

Serous Tumors

Serous Cystadenoma: Benign, unilateral, cystic spaces with serous epithelium.

Large cystic mass, unilateral.
 

Serous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, often bilateral, cystic and solid components.

Bilateral involvement in 30%, elevated CA-125.

Mucinous Tumors

Mucinous Cystadenoma (Option A): Benign, unilateral, filled with mucinous fluid.

Large, unilateral mass.
 

Mucinous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, unilateral, mucinous epithelial lining.

May rupture and spread to the peritoneum.

Endometrioid Tumors

Endometrioid Carcinoma (Option C): Arises from endometrial-like tissue, solid and cystic.

Solid and cystic components, associated with endometriosis.

Clear Cell Tumors

Clear Cell Carcinoma: Clear cytoplasm due to glycogen accumulation.

Advanced stage, associated with endometriosis.

Brenner Tumors (Transitional Cell)

Brenner Tumor (Option D): Transitional epithelial cells resembling urinary tract epithelium.

Rare, usually benign.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and a palpable left adnexal mass. Ultrasound reveals a unilateral ovarian mass that is predominantly solid. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of LDH and hCG. She has no family history of ovarian cancer.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is a young woman with a unilateral ovarian mass and elevated LDH and hCG levels, which are markers commonly associated with germ cell tumors. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Dysgerminoma.

Epithelial ovarian tumors are generally bilateral and affect older women, making them less likely in this young patient with a unilateral mass.

 

Ovarian Tumor Markers:

 

CA 125

AFP

HCG

PLAP

LDH

Inhibin, AMH

Others

Epithelial

+

-

-

-

-

-

HE4

Dysgerminoma

-

-

+/-

+

+

-

No AFP

Granulosa cell

-

-

-

-

-

+

  

Endodermal sinus / Yolk sac tumor

-

+

-

-

-

Alpha-1 Antitrypsin is specific

No HCG

Embryonal Tumor

-

+

+

-

+

-

  

Choriocarcinoma

-

-

+

-

-

-

  

Teratoma

-

+

-

-

-

-

  

 

Serous cystadenoma (Option A): A type of epithelial ovarian tumor, usually benign and can be either unilateral or bilateral. However, they are more common in older women.

 

Mucinous cystadenoma (Option B): Another type of epithelial ovarian tumor, mucinous cystadenomas are typically unilateral but are still more common in older women. They also do not usually present with elevated AFP and hCG levels.

 

Endometrioid carcinoma (Option D): This is a malignant epithelial ovarian tumor and is more common in older women.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the role of radiotherapy in the treatment of ovarian tumors is most accurate?

choices.text: Radiotherapy is highly effective for the primary treatment of epithelial ovarian carcinoma.
Radiotherapy is typically used for palliation in recurrent ovarian cancer to alleviate symptoms such as pain and bleeding.
Radiotherapy is primarily used to treat primary ovarian tumors rather than metastatic disease.
Dysgerminoma is the only type of ovarian tumor that is radioresistant.

questions.solution:
• Most ovarian tumors are not highly responsive to radiotherapy i.e., they are radioresistant.
  • Dysgerminoma is the only ovarian tumor considered radiosensitive.

Hence, Radiotherapy is mainly used in a palliative setting for recurrent ovarian cancer. It helps to alleviate symptoms such as pain and bleeding. It can also be employed to manage metastasis from ovarian cancer.

In cervical cancer (Ca cervix), radiotherapy is a mainstay of treatment, whereas, for ovarian cancer, radiotherapy is useless as a primary treatment because of high morbidity.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with abdominal distension and discomfort. Transvaginal ultrasound confirms a complex ovarian mass. CA-125 levels are elevated. Further imaging and biopsy confirm the diagnosis of high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma. She undergoes primary debulking surgery, and the tumor is staged as advanced (Stage III) disease.

Which of the following chemotherapy regimens is most appropriate as the first-line adjuvant treatment for this patient following her surgery?
questions.solution:
Following primary debulking surgery, the standard first-line adjuvant chemotherapy regimen for epithelial ovarian cancer includes a combination of paclitaxel and carboplatin.

  • These drugs are given intravenously every 3 weeks for six cycles.

Chemotherapy for other types of ovarian carcinomas:

  • Germ cell tumors: Bleomycin-Platinum-Etoposide (BEP) Regimen; Vincristine-Bleomycin-Platinum (VBP) Regimen.
  • Sex cord tumors: Surgery alone sufficient. For BRCA-associated tumors, Platins+PARP ( Poly ADP Ribose Polymerase) inhibitors like Olaparib are used.

Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy:
For patients with advanced ovarian cancer, especially those who may not be ideal candidates for immediate surgery due to extensive disease, neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NACT) is an option.

  • NACT involves administering chemotherapy before surgical intervention.
  • Given as 3 cycles before surgery and 3 cycles after surgery.
  • It increases the chances of optimal debulking - This surgery after initial neoadjuvant chemotherapy is called interval debulking.

Note:

  • Women relapsing after 6 months of primary chemotherapy - Platinum-sensitive ovarian cancer
  • Women relapsing within 6 months of primary chemotherapy - Platinum-resistant ovarian cancer

 

Methotrexate and leucovorin rescue (Option A): This regimen is used primarily for gestational trophoblastic disease.

 

Vincristine, doxorubicin, and cyclophosphamide (VAC) (Option C): This combination is used for certain types of sarcomas.

 

Cisplatin and etoposide (Option D): Commonly used for testicular cancer and small cell lung cancer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of progressive abdominal distension and discomfort over the past few months. A pelvic examination reveals a large, irregular adnexal mass. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a complex ovarian mass with ascites, and peritoneal nodules. Additionally, there are small nodules on the diaphragm and involvement of the retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Based on the FIGO staging system for ovarian carcinoma, what is the most likely stage of her disease?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical findings of macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis (peritoneal nodules, diaphragm nodules) and retroperitoneal lymph node involvement, the most likely FIGO stage for this patient's ovarian carcinoma is Stage IIIC.

FIGO's staging for cancer of the ovary, fallopian tube, and peritoneum:

FIGO Stage

Substage

Description

Stage I

 

Tumor confined to the ovaries or fallopian tubes.

TNM: T1‐N0‐M0

 

Stage I A

Tumor limited to one ovary or fallopian tube, capsule intact, no tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface, no malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings.

TNM: T1a‐N0‐M0

 

Stage I B

Tumor involves both ovaries or fallopian tubes, capsules intact, no tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface, no malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings.

TNM: T1b‐N0‐M0

 

Stage I C

Tumor limited to one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes, with any of the following:

 

  • Stage I C1 - Surgical spill. TNM: T1c1‐N0‐M0

  • Stage I C2 - Capsule rupture before surgery or tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface. TNM: T1c2‐N0‐M0

  • Stage I C3 - Malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings. TNM: T1c3‐N0‐M0

Stage II

 

Tumor involves one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes with pelvic extension (below the pelvic brim) or primary peritoneal cancer.

TNM: T2‐N0‐M0

 

Stage IIA

Extension and/or implants on uterus and/or fallopian tubes/ovaries.

TNM: T2a‐N0‐M0

 

Stage IIB

Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues.

TNM: T2b‐N0‐M0

Stage III

 

Tumor involves one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes, or primary peritoneal cancer, with cytologically or histologically confirmed spread to the peritoneum outside the pelvis and/or metastasis to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes.

TNM: T1/T2‐N1‐M0

 

Stage IIIA1

Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only (with or without microscopic peritoneal involvement beyond the pelvis).

 

 

Stage IIIA1(i)

Metastasis ≤10 mm.

TNM: T1‐N0‐M0

Stage IIIA1(ii)

Metastasis >10 mm.

TNM: T1‐N0‐M0

 

Stage IIIA2

Microscopic extrapelvic (above the pelvic brim) peritoneal involvement ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes.

TNM: T3a2‐N0/N1‐M0

 

Stage IIIB

Macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis ≤2 cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes.

TNM: T3b‐N0/N1‐M0

 

Stage IIIC

Macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis >2 cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes (includes extension to capsule of liver and spleen without parenchymal involvement of either organ).

TNM: T3c‐N0/N1‐M0

Stage IV

 

Distant metastasis excluding peritoneal metastases.

TNM: Any T, any N, M1

 

Stage IVA

Pleural effusion with positive cytology.

 

Stage IVB

Parenchymal metastases and metastases to extra-abdominal organs (including inguinal lymph nodes and lymph nodes outside of the abdominal cavity).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset severe right lower abdominal pain that is sharp and constant. Pelvic ultrasound reveals a 6 cm complex cystic mass in the ovary. Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Complication of ruptured ovarian cyst causing acute appendicitis
Due to the peritoneal cavity being filled with mucinous material from ovarian cysts
Doppler shows viable blood supply to the ovary

questions.solution:
• Ovarian torsion is a common complication of ovarian masses, particularly dermoid cysts. Caused by sudden or violent movement, it can initiate the twist along its pedicle compromising the blood supply to the ovaries.
  • Management would include detorsion, consideration for cystectomy or oophorectomy depending on the degree of necrosis of tissues or further, ovariopexy could be considered in the end.
  • Ovarian torsion is an emergency that requires immediate surgery. The surgeon performs detorsion and ovariopexy, which involves attaching the ovary to the pelvic sidewall to prevent future torsion.

 

Complications of Ovarian tumor

Rupture

Release of tumor contents, causing acute abdominal pain and potential peritonitis.

Hemorrhage

Internal bleeding within the tumor or peritoneal cavity leads to abdominal pain.

Ovarian Torsion

Twisting of the ovary compromises blood supply and causes severe pain.

Pseudomyxoma Peritonei

Mucinous material fills the peritoneal cavity, causing adhesions; often associated with mucinous cystadenomas.

Extraperitoneal Spread

Tumor growth outside the peritoneal cavity, complicates surgical removal.

Malignant Change

Benign tumors can transform into malignant ones, increasing the risk of metastasis.

Infection

Infection of the tumor, leads to abscess formation and systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain distension and a palpable pelvic mass. Imaging studies reveal a large, predominantly solid ovarian mass with areas of cystic degeneration. Serum alpha 1-fetoprotein levels are markedly elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
High levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) are found in the blood of patients with Endodermal sinus tumors. Usually unilateral and affects girls between the ages of 15 and 25

 

Ovarian Tumor Marker

Tumor Type

CA 125
  • Epithelial

AFP
  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor
  • Embryonal Tumor

hCG
  • Embryonal Tumor
  • Choriocarcinoma

LDH
  • Dysgerminoma
  • Embryonal Tumor

Inhibin
  • Granulosa cell tumor

α-1 antitrypsin
  • Endodermal sinus tumor


 

Ovarian Tumor Markers:

 

CA 125

AFP

HCG

PLAP

LDH

Inhibin, AMH

Others

Epithelial

+

-

HE4

Dysgerminoma

+/-

No AFP

Granulosa cell

+

  

Endodermal sinus / Yolk sac tumor

-

Alpha-1 Antitrypsin is specific

No HCG

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about ovarian masses in pregnancy?

choices.text: Malignant ovarian tumors require surgery immediately after pregnancy
Benign ovarian tumors are removed preferably in the first trimester
Corpus luteum cyst must be operated before the 12th week of gestation

questions.solution:
Ovarian tumor/mass management in Pregnancy :

  • A corpus luteum cyst typically regresses on its own after the 12th week of pregnancy and can be monitored. (Option C)
  • Benign tumors (>10cm) should be surgically removed during the second trimester, between the 14th and 16th weeks of pregnancy (Option B).
    • Surgery earlier in the pregnancy increases the risk of abortion, while surgery in the third trimester increases surgical difficulty due to the enlarged uterus and increases the risk of preterm labor.
    • If the tumor is discovered late in the pregnancy, it should be removed soon after delivery to prevent torsion and infection.
  • Malignant ovarian tumors require surgery as early as possible, regardless of the duration of the pregnancy (Option D)
  • In C-section delivery, the tumor can be removed during the surgery as well.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of gastric cancer, presents with abdominal discomfort and bloating for the past few months. Pelvic ultrasound reveals ovarian masses. Biopsy shows signet ring cells within the ovarian tissue. Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Krukenberg tumors are metastatic tumors of the ovary primarily from the gastrointestinal tract, mainly the stomach. They are characterized by the presence of signet ring cells. Krukenberg tumors always retain the shape of the normal ovary.

Gross pathology and histopathology of Krukenberg tumor

 

Krukenberg tumors

Definition

Krukenberg tumors are metastatic tumors of the ovary, typically originating from the gastrointestinal tract, especially the stomach.

Bilateral involvement is common. (Option A)

Primary Sites
  • Stomach: 70%
  • Large Bowel: 15%
  • Breast: 6%

Shape and Consistency
  • Retain the general shape of a normal ovary
  • Solid and waxy consistency (Option C)

Histopathology

Characterized by the presence of signet-ring cells, where the nucleus is displaced to one side by intracellular mucin giving the cells a "ring-like" structure.

Spread Mechanism

Ovarian involvement occurs primarily through retrograde lymphatic spread. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most commonly associated with the development of ovarian epithelial surface tumors?

choices.text: High parity and use of oral contraceptives
Familial history of BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations

questions.solution:
Risk Factors for Ovarian Epithelial Tumors

Protective factors for ovarian cancer

Age between 45 and 60 years

Physical exercise

Nulliparous or of low parity (higher estrogen exposure)

Related to ovulation-anovulation (multiparity, OCP, breastfeeding) (Option C)

Women with previous PCOS, or on Tamoxifen (higher estrogen exposure)

Surgeries- hysterectomy, tubal ligation, salpingectomy

High-calorie, High-fat diet (Higher estrogen exposure)

  

Genetic predisposition BRCA-1 and BRCA-2 gene mutation (Option D)

Late menopause and early menarche (high estrogen exposure)

Family history of breast and Gastrointestinal cancer

Multiple cycles of ovulation induction

Scars

↑ Scars → Epithelium→ Overhealing → Epithelial ovarian CA

Asbestos Exposure

  

 

Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection (Option A): HPV infection is associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer.

Chronic inflammation and endometriosis (Option B): Chronic inflammation and endometriosis are linked with developing ovarian cancer, however, the mechanism is not fully understood and it is not the most common association.

High parity and use of oral contraceptives (Option C): High parity and use of oral contraceptives are protective factors against ovarian cancer as a result of reduced ovulation and reduced gonadotropin levels

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive hair growth on her face, chest, and back over the past six months. She also mentions recent changes in her menstrual cycle, including irregular periods. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of testosterone and DHEA-S and normal ACTH levels.

Which of the following causes is most likely responsible for the rapid onset of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumor is the most likely cause of the rapid onset of hirsutism and menstrual irregularities in this patient. These tumors are small and solid in consistency and the cut surface shows a yellowish tinge with areas of haemorrhage and necrosis.

These tumors are known to secrete androgens, leading to elevated levels of testosterone and DHEA-S, which can cause rapid development of symptoms such as hirsutism, acne, and menstrual disturbances.

Onset of Hirsutism

Most Common Cause

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)

Rapid Onset

Ovarian (Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumor) or adrenal tumors

Puberty Onset

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

Adult Onset

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)

 

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (Option A): Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) typically has a more gradual onset and is characterized by chronic symptoms.

 

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (Option B): Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) usually presents in childhood or adolescence, and symptoms typically progress more gradually.

 

Cushing's Syndrome (Option D): Cushing's Syndrome is associated with elevated ACTH levels, and while it can cause hirsutism, it also presents with other systemic signs like weight gain, hypertension, and glucose intolerance.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother with complaints of breast development and vaginal bleeding. An ultrasound reveals a mixed solid and cystic ovarian mass measuring 5 cm. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of inhibin B and estradiol. The HPE slide is given below:-



What is the next step in the management of the patient?

choices.text: Observation and follow-up with repeat ultrasound
Hormonal therapy to manage precocious puberty
Chemotherapy to reduce the size of the tumor

questions.solution:
• Laparotomy with unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is the next step in the management of this patient, as the presence of a mixed solid and cystic ovarian mass, elevated inhibin B and estradiol levels, and signs of precocious puberty are highly suggestive of juvenile granulosa cell tumor, a variant of granulosa cell tumor.

  • The HPE findings for Granulosa cell tumour are round or polygonal cells with granular eosinophilic cytoplasm with ill-defined borders, coffee bean nuclei and granulosa cells arranged in small clusters around a central cavity (Call-Exner Bodies). However, coffee bean nuclei and Call-Exner bodies are less prominent in the juvenile variant and more prominent in the adult variant.

  • Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is the optimum treatment for children or women of reproductive age. Metastatic disease and recurrences treated with BEP chemotherapeutic regimens.

 

Sex Cord Tumours

A. Granulosa Cell Tumors

Incidence

  • 70% of all ovarian SCSTs are granulosa cell tumors

  • 2% of all ovarian neoplasms

Types

  • Adult form (95%)

  • Juvenile form (5%)

Characteristics

  • Slow growing

  • Solid or cystic or mixed

  • Cut section shows yellow/orange due to lipid content

HPE Appearance

  • Round/polygonal cells with granular eosinophilic cytoplasm

  • Coffee bean nuclei

  • Call-Exner bodies (Pathognomonic)

 

Hormonal Activity & Markers

  • Secrete inhibin B, estrogen, and AMH

Clinical Features

  • Prior to puberty: Precocious puberty

  • Childbearing period: Abnormal uterine bleeding

  • Postmenopausal: Bleeding often with endometrial hyperplasia or adenocarcinoma

Prognosis

  • Good overall prognosis

  • 5-year survival rate for stage I disease is about 95%

B. Theca Cell Tumors

Presentation

Presents after Menopause

Characteristics

Solid yellow tumor containing lipoid material

Hormonal Activity & Markers

Estrogen

Clinical Features

Estrogenic (causes post-menopausal bleed)

Usually Benign

C. Sertoli Leydig Tumors / Arrhenoblastomas

Incidence

0.5% of all ovarian tumours, 5% of all SCST’s

Characteristics

Small, solid, unilateral tumor and on HPE Reinke crystals are pathognomonic.

Hormonal Activity & Markers

Androgens, Inhibin, AFP

Clinical Features

  • Hirsutism (Male pattern baldness, excessive hair growth) - Reversible

  • Virilization (Hoarseness, Breast atrophy, Clitoromegaly) - Permanent

  • Oligomenorrhea to Amenorrhea

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain and a palpable pelvic mass. She reports not having a menstrual period for the past two months. A physical examination reveals a firm, rubbery pelvic mass. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of hCG and LDH. An ultrasound reveals a 10 cm solid ovarian mass, and a laparotomy is performed. Below is the slide after the HPE examination of the biopsy.

 



What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and laboratory findings, along with the histopathological features seen in the slide (large polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm & dark stained nucleoli & back-to-back arrangement) are features of a dysgerminoma. There is also lymphocytic infiltration of fibrous septa and features are similar to seminoma.

 

Dysgerminomas are malignant germ cell tumors typically occurring in young women and are associated with elevated hCG and LDH levels.

Types of Germ Cell Tumors

Description

Teratoma

Mature cystic teratoma of the ovary

Most common germ cell tumor. They have components of all 3 germ layers

2 Types:-

  • Mature Teratoma (MC GCT Overall)- Dermoid/Cystic, Benign
  • Immature Teratoma- Malignant, monoclonal type

Dysgerminoma
  • MC malignant germ cell tumor
  • HPE- Seminoma type cells seen
  • Tumour Marker- hCG, PLAP, LDH

Yolk Sac Tumor

 

Schiller Duval bodies
  • The most malignant and worst prognosis
  • HPE- Schiller Duval bodies: Central vessels with tumor cells around a cystic space
  • Tumour Marker- AFP, Alpha-1 antitrypsin

Embryonal Cancer
  • Highly aggressive malignant tumour
  • Tumour Marker- AFP, hCG, Estrogen

Choriocarcinoma
  • 2 Types:-
  1. Gestational Choriocarcinoma
  2. Non Gestational Choriocarcinoma
  • Tumour Marker- hCG

Mixed Type
  • Presence of more than one germ cell element (Dysgerminoma + yolk sac tumor)
  • Tumour Markers- hCG, AFP

questions.text: All of the following are features of borderline epithelial tumors of the ovary except:

choices.text: Presence of nuclear atypia of varying degrees

questions.solution:
Borderline epithelial tumors of the ovary have a low malignant potential, intermediate between benign and malignant tumors of the ovary.

Features of Borderline Epithelial Tumors
  • Low malignant potential; intermediate between benign and malignant.
  • Constitute 10-20% of all epithelial tumors of the ovary.
  • Presence of nuclear atypia of varying degrees. (Option B)
  • Increased cellular mitotic activity. (Option D)
  • No invasion of ovarian stroma.
  • Detachment of cellular clusters from the sites of origin.
  • Epithelial hyperplasia, pseudostratification, micropapillary projections, tufting (Option A)

Treatment (Young patient)
  • Ovarian cystectomy
  • Unilateral oophorectomy

Treatment (Old patient)
  • Total hysterectomy
  • Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
  • Omentectomy

questions.text: 65 year old woman presents with dyspnea, dry cough & painful abdominal distention with a right sided solid adnexal mass. The ovarian tumor was removed and was found to be benign and her symptoms resolved after tumor removal. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Ovarian Fibroma

Explanation:

Her clinical findings are in favor of Meig's Syndrome - triad of benign ovarian fibroma + pleural effusion + ascites.

Fibroma is the most common benign solid ovarian neoplasm. It is also the most common sex cord stromal cell tumor, primarily occurring in postmenopausal women, although they can occur in any age group. They are hormonally inactive tumors. 

They can be associated with ascites or hydrothorax as a result of increased capillary permeability thought to be the result of  vascular endothelial growth factor production. Meigs Syndrome (ovarian fibroma, ascites and pleural effusion) usually resolves after surgical excision of the fibroma.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with a large adnexal mass detected on a routine pelvic examination. She complains of intermittent pelvic pain and bloating over the past few months. Ultrasound imaging reveals a 10 cm complex ovarian mass diagnosed as germ cell tumor. What is the most appropriate surgical approach in this scenario?

choices.text: Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with staging and preservation of the contralateral ovary and uterus
Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with omentectomy and lymph node dissection
Laparoscopic cystectomy to remove only the cystic portion of the mass

questions.solution:
The best surgical approach for a young woman with an ovarian mass who wishes to retain her fertility is unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with staging, while preserving the contralateral ovary and the uterus. This option allows for removing the affected ovary and properly staging the disease, which is critical for diagnosing and planning further treatment if necessary.

 

Normally for ovarian tumors, the surgery is TAH + BSO (Total Abdominal Hysterectomy with Bilateral Salpingo-Oophorectomy).

Exceptions:

  • Conservative: Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy no hysterectomy (to preserve fertility)
    • Germ cell tumor
    • Sex cord tumor in young females
    • Stage IA og epithelial tumor and family not completed
  • Debulking surgery (Cytoreductive surgery)
    • Advanced stages (Stage 3,4)

 

Most patients require a combined approach, starting with maximal debulking surgery followed by chemotherapy. Surgery is typically the initial step to determine the disease stage, assess its spread, and remove as much of the disease as possible from the abdomen and pelvis.

 

Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (Option A): TAH + BSO would result in the loss of fertility and is more appropriate for older patients or those who do not desire future fertility.

 

Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with omentectomy and lymph node dissection (Option C): Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with omentectomy and lymph node dissection is a radical surgery, generally reserved for confirmed malignancy, where fertility preservation is not a concern.

 

Laparoscopic cystectomy to remove only the cystic portion of the mass (Option D): Laparoscopic cystectomy to remove only the cystic portion of the mass would be insufficient if the mass is malignant, and it would not provide adequate staging information.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about HE4 and the Risk of Ovarian Malignancy Algorithm (ROMA) score is correct?

choices.text: HE4 is a marker that is specific for mucinous ovarian cancer.
The ROMA score combines HE4 and CA-125 levels with menopausal status to assess the risk of ovarian cancer.
HE4 is only useful in the diagnosis of ovarian cancer in postmenopausal women.
The ROMA score is primarily used to predict the risk of breast cancer.

questions.solution:
ROMA (Risk of Ovarian Malignancy Algorithm):

The combination of CA125 + HE4 (Human epididymal protein 4) tests, along with menopausal status, is used to help determine the likelihood of finding a malignancy on surgery in women with an adnexal mass. The combination of CA125 + HE4 accurately determines the likelihood of malignancy

 

Human epididymal protein 4 (HE4):

  • HE4: > 94% specificity; unaffected by endometriotic cysts
  • Differentiates benign from malignant ovarian tumors
  • Useful for early-stage ovarian cancer detection
  • Elevated in most serous and endometrioid tumors
  • Increased in 50% of clear cell tumors
  • Not elevated in mucinous tumors
  • Combined with CA-125, it detects ovarian and endometrial cancer


 

ROMA score: Risk of Malignancy Algorithm

Pre-menopausal Predictive Index (PI): 12 + 2.38 x LN(HE4) + 0.0626 x LN (CA-125)

Post-menopausal Predictive Index (PI): 8.09 + 1.04 x LN(HE4) + 0.732 x LN (CA-125)

ROMA(%): 100 X Exp PI/ (1 + Exp PI)

ROMAcut-off: 7.4% for premenopausal women

25.3% postmenopausal women

 

HE4 is a marker that is specific for mucinous ovarian cancer (Option A): HE4 is a marker used for ovarian cancer but is not specific for mucinous ovarian cancer.

 

HE4 is only useful in the diagnosis of ovarian cancer in postmenopausal women (Option C): HE4 is useful in both premenopausal and postmenopausal women for ovarian cancer risk assessment.

 

The ROMA score is primarily used to predict the risk of breast cancer (Option D): The ROMA score is specifically designed for assessing the risk of ovarian cancer, not breast cancer.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a pelvic mass detected during a routine physical examination. To assess the risk of ovarian malignancy, the Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI) is calculated. The formula for RMI involves ultrasound score, menopausal status, and serum CA-125 levels. Which of the following correctly describes how the RMI score is calculated?

choices.text: RMI = Ultrasound score + Menopausal status score + CA-125 level
RMI = (Ultrasound score × Menopausal status score) + CA-125 level
RMI = Ultrasound score × Menopausal status score × CA-125 level
RMI = (Ultrasound score × Menopausal status score) ÷ CA-125 level

questions.solution:
RMI combines 3 pre-surgical features:

  • Serum CA125 (CA125)
  • Menopausal status (M)
  • Ultrasound score (U)

The RMI is a product of the ultrasound scan score, the menopausal status, and the serum CA125 level (IU/ml).

RMI = U x M x CA125

  • The Ultrasound report is scored 1 point for each of the following characteristics. U=0 for an Ultrasound score of 0

Ultrasound Report (1 point for each) (U)

Multilocular cysts

Solid areas

Metastases

ascites

Bilateral lesions
  • The classification of ‘post-menopausal’ is a woman who has had permanent cessation of menstruation for at least 12 consecutive months or a woman over 50 who has had a hysterectomy.

Menopausal status (M)

Score

Pre-menopausal

1

Post-menopausal

3
  • Serum CA125 is measured in IU/ml and can vary between 0 and hundreds/thousands of units.

 

The other options incorrectly represent the calculation of the RMI.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with persistent abdominal bloating, early fullness, and lower abdominal pain for the past three months. On physical examination, a firm, non-tender mass is palpated in the right lower abdomen. A transvaginal ultrasound identifies a 7 cm complex ovarian mass with both cystic and solid components, along with septations. Her serum CA-125 level is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, combined with the findings of a complex ovarian mass with solid and cystic components and elevated CA-125 levels, are indicative of epithelial ovarian carcinoma.

 

Diagnosis of Ovarian tumors

  • Ultrasound: Ultrasound features of malignant masses:
    • >10 cm in size
    • Bilateral
    • Variable consistency (solid component)
    • Thick septa
    • Papillary outgrowth (excrescences) from septa
    • High vascularity in septa
  • CT and MRI indicate the extent of the tumor spread.
  • Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) and ascitic fluid cytology yield a high false-negative report.
  • Tumor markers.
    • CEA more than 5 ng/mL. (normal 2.5-5 ng/mL.) is reported in endometrioid, Brenner tumor, mucinous tumor, colonic, liver, breast and lung metastasis.
    • CA-125 is a glycoprotein surface antigen raised in 80% of epithelial tumors, but is not very specific, as it is also raised in abdominal tuberculosis and endometriosis as well.
    • AFP, hCG, NB/70K, placental alkaline phosphatase and lactate dehydrogenase (1000 U/L) are the tissue markers for germ cell tumors.
  • Management of ovarian enlargement guidelines:
    • Enlargement >8cm during pregnancy should be followed up.
      • If functional cyst <7cm - Contraceptives and observation for 6 months.
      • If persistent or chocolate cyst - Conservative surgery
    • In postmenopausal women, CA 125 levels should be checked.
      • Simple, unilocular, <8cm cysts and normal CA 125 ( <35 IU/mL)- Conservative management.
      • Enlarged ovaries >8cm or any symptomatic ovarian tumor - Early Laparotomy.

 

Simple ovarian cyst (Option A): Simple ovarian cysts typically do not present with such complexity or elevated CA-125.

 

Benign serous cystadenoma (Option B): Benign serous cystadenomas generally appear as simple cystic structures and are usually unilocular (one compartment) and filled with clear fluid. They do not commonly cause elevated CA-125 levels.

 

Ovarian endometrioma (Option D): Ovarian endometriomas are linked with endometriosis and have a different clinical presentation, typically without significant CA-125 elevation.
